TextEquiv.Unicode: the holy Ghost,
And although God did largely, clear
ly, plainely ad simplie, reveale his
word to the world by the Patriarches,
by Moses, by the Priestes and Pro
phets, yet did hee in the last times of
all, by his Sonne, set it forth most
clearely, simply, and aboundantly to al
the worlde. For the verye and onely
begotten Sonne of God the father, as
the Prophetes had foretolde, descen
ding from heaven doth fulsill all what
soever they foretolde, and by the space
almost of three yeeres doeth teach all
pointes of godlines. For saith John,
No man at any time hath seene God,
the onely begotten sonne which is in
the bosome of the father, he hath de,
clared him. The Lord himselfe more
over, saith to his Disciples, Al things
which I have heard of my Father have
I made knowne to you. And againe he
saieth, I am the light of the worlde:
whosoever doth follow me doeth not
walke in darkenes, but shall have the
light of life. Our Lorde also did teach,
that to him which woulde enter into
Heaven and be saved, the heavenly re
generation was needefull: because in
the first byrth man is borne to death,
in the second to life. But that that re
generation is made perfect in us by ye
spirite of God, which instructeth our
hearts in faith, I say in faith in Christ
who dyed for our sinnes, & rose againe
for our justification. He taught that
by that faith they which believe are
justified: and that out of the same faith
doe growe sundry fruites of charitie
and innocencie, to the bringing foorth
whereof, he did most earnestly exhorte
them. He taught furthemmore, that he
was the fulfilling or fulnes of the law
and the Prophets, & did also approve
and expound the doctrin of Moses and
the Prophetes. To doctrine he joyned

the holy Ghost, And although God did largely, clear ly, plainely ad simplie, reveale his word to the world by the Patriarches, by Moses, by the Priestes and Pro phets, yet did hee in the last times of all, by his Sonne, set it forth most clearely, simply, and aboundantly to al the worlde. For the verye and onely begotten Sonne of God the father, as the Prophetes had foretolde, descen ding from heaven doth fulsill all what soever they foretolde, and by the space almost of three yeeres doeth teach all pointes of godlines. For saith John, No man at any time hath seene God, the onely begotten sonne which is in the bosome of the father, he hath de, clared him. The Lord himselfe more over, saith to his Disciples, Al things which I have heard of my Father have I made knowne to you. And againe he saieth, I am the light of the worlde: whosoever doth follow me doeth not walke in darkenes, but shall have the light of life. Our Lorde also did teach, that to him which woulde enter into Heaven and be saved, the heavenly re generation was needefull: because in the first byrth man is borne to death, in the second to life. But that that re generation is made perfect in us by ye spirite of God, which instructeth our hearts in faith, I say in faith in Christ who dyed for our sinnes, & rose againe for our justification. He taught that by that faith they which believe are justified: and that out of the same faith doe growe sundry fruites of charitie and innocencie, to the bringing foorth whereof, he did most earnestly exhorte them. He taught furthemmore, that he was the fulfilling or fulnes of the law and the Prophets, & did also approve and expound the doctrin of Moses and the Prophetes. To doctrine he joyned
diverse miracles and benefits, where
by he declared that hee himselfe was
that light of the world, and the migh
ty & bountiful redeemer of the worlde.
And, to the intent that his docrine &
benefites might be knowen to all the
worlde, he chose to himselfe witnesses,
whom he called Apostles, because hee
purposed to sende them to Preache
throughout the worlde. Those witnes
ses were simple men, innocents, just,
tellers of trueth, without deceipt or
subtilties, and in al pointes holie and
good: whose names it is verie profita
ble often to repeate in the Congrega
tion. The names of the Apostles are
these, Peter and Andrew, James and
John, Philippe and Bartholomewe,
Thomas and Mathew, James the sonne
of Alphe, and Judas his brother, whose
surname was Thaddeeus, Simon and
Judas lscariot, into whose roome (be
cause he had betrayed the Lord) came
Sainct Matthias. These had he by the
space almost of three yeares , hearers
of his heavenly doctrine, and beholders
of his divine workes. These after his
ascension into the Heavens, did he by
the holie ghost sent downe from hea
ven, instruct with all kinde of facul
ties. For, as they were in the Scrip
tures passing skilfull: so were they not
unskilfull or wanting eloquence in a
ny tongue. And being once after this
manner instructed, they departe out
of the Citie of Jerusalem, and passe
through the compasse of the earth,
preaching to all people and nations
that which they had received to preach
of the saviour of the world, & the Lord
Jesus Christ. And when for certaine
yeares, they had preached by worde of
mouth, then did they also set downe in
writing that which they had prea
ched. For some, verily, write an hi
storie of the words and deeds of Christ,

diverse miracles and benefits, where by he declared that hee himselfe was that light of the world, and the migh ty & bountiful redeemer of the worlde. And, to the intent that his docrine & benefites might be knowen to all the worlde, he chose to himselfe witnesses, whom he called Apostles, because hee purposed to sende them to Preache throughout the worlde. Those witnes ses were simple men, innocents, just, tellers of trueth, without deceipt or subtilties, and in al pointes holie and good: whose names it is verie profita ble often to repeate in the Congrega tion. The names of the Apostles are these, Peter and Andrew, James and John, Philippe and Bartholomewe, Thomas and Mathew, James the sonne of Alphe, and Judas his brother, whose surname was Thaddeeus, Simon and Judas lscariot, into whose roome (be cause he had betrayed the Lord) came Sainct Matthias. These had he by the space almost of three yeares , hearers of his heavenly doctrine, and beholders of his divine workes. These after his ascension into the Heavens, did he by the holie ghost sent downe from hea ven, instruct with all kinde of facul ties. For, as they were in the Scrip tures passing skilfull: so were they not unskilfull or wanting eloquence in a ny tongue. And being once after this manner instructed, they departe out of the Citie of Jerusalem, and passe through the compasse of the earth, preaching to all people and nations that which they had received to preach of the saviour of the world, & the Lord Jesus Christ. And when for certaine yeares, they had preached by worde of mouth, then did they also set downe in writing that which they had prea ched. For some, verily, write an hi storie of the words and deeds of Christ,
